principles: Complete each component to earn base points
Streaks can add bonus percentages when enabled
Mastery achievements can unlock multipliers when configured
Badges can require: Mastery + Completion + Capstone

content: Wheelock's Latin
7th Edition • with Workbook (3rd Edition Revised)
Complete Grading Rubric & Reward Point System
1. Grading Philosophy
This system follows the principle: "Process Earns, Mastery Multiplies."
Students earn steady base points for completing daily work consistently. Bonus multipliers and thematic mastery badges reward demonstrated understanding and long-term retention.

Latin is traditionally taught as a reading language rather than a conversational one. Accordingly, the speaking component is reduced to pronunciation and reading aloud (10%), with the freed weight redistributed to daily practice and flashcard mastery. Reading authentic Latin texts from the Locī Antīquī earns bonus points.
2. Course Structure

Wheelock's Latin contains 40 chapters (Capita) covering comprehensive Latin grammar from basic verb conjugations through advanced subjunctive constructions. The course uses both the main textbook and the companion Workbook, weighted equally.

sections.heading: 2.1 Unit Breakdown
tables: Future/Imperfect; Possum; 3rd Declension Nouns; 3rd Conjugation Present
Demonstratives (Hic, Ille, Iste, Is); 4th Conjugation; Perfect Active System
Reflexives; i-Stem Nouns; Numerals; 3rd Declension Adjectives
Relative Pronoun; Present Passive; Perfect Passive; 4th Declension
Midterm: All 5 Declensions + Complete Active/Passive Voice System
3rd/4th Conj. Passive; 5th Declension; Participles; Ablative Absolute
Infinitives; Indirect Statement; Comparison; Subjunctive Introduction
Subjunctive Uses; Cum Clauses; Ferō; Volō, Mālō, Nōlō; Adverbs
Conditions; Deponent Verbs; Dative Uses; Jussive Noun Clauses; Fīō
Eō; Place/Time; Relative Characteristic; Gerund/Gerundive; Fear Clauses

sections.heading: 2.2 Chapter Content Overview
content: Each of the 40 chapters covers specific grammatical concepts with vocabulary, paradigms, and practice sentences.
3. Per-Chapter Components
Each of the 40 chapters includes the following graded components:
4. Grade Weight Distribution
The course grade is calculated from five categories. Because Latin is primarily a reading language, the speaking component is reduced to 10% (pronunciation/reading aloud only).
tables: Verbs: 1st & 2nd Conjugations; Adverbs; Reading and Translating
1st Declension Nouns & Adjectives; Prepositions; Conjunctions; Interjections
2nd Declension Masculine Nouns & Adjectives; Apposition; Word Order
2nd Declension Neuters; Adjectives; Present of Sum; Predicate Nominatives
1st & 2nd Conjugations: Future and Imperfect; Adjectives in -er
Demonstratives Hic, Ille, Iste; Special -īus Adjectives
Personal Pronouns Ego, Tū, Is; Demonstratives Is and Idem
Reflexive Pronouns and Possessives; Intensive Pronoun
i-Stem Nouns (3rd Decl.); Ablatives of Means, Accompaniment, Manner
Numerals; Genitive of the Whole; Ablative with Numerals and Time
1st & 2nd Conjugations: Present System Passive; Ablative of Agent
Perfect Passive System; Interrogative Pronouns and Adjectives
4th Declension; Ablatives of Place from Which and Separation
5th Declension; Ablative of Place Where; Summary of Ablative Uses
Ablative Absolute; Passive Periphrastic; Dative of Agent
Comparison of Adjectives; Ablative of Comparison
Subjunctive Mood; Present Subjunctive; Jussive and Purpose Clauses
Imperfect Subjunctive; Present/Imperfect Subjunctive of Sum/Possum; Result Clauses
Perfect & Pluperfect Subjunctive; Indirect Questions; Sequence of Tenses
Formation & Comparison of Adverbs; Volō, Mālō, Nōlō; Proviso Clauses
Deponent Verbs; Ablative with Special Deponents
Dative with Adjectives, Special Verbs, and Compounds
Conjugation of Eō; Place and Time Constructions
Relative Clauses of Characteristic; Dative of Reference; Supines
-Ne, Num, Nōnne in Direct Questions; Fear Clauses; Genitive/Ablative of Description
Reading Latin text with proper pronunciation

sections.heading: 4.2 Detailed Breakdown
content: Daily Practice — Written (25%)
Textbook Exercises (Exercitationes, Sententiae Antīquae): 12.5% of total grade
Workbook Exercises: 12.5% of total grade
Flashcard System (25%)
Flashcard Creation (all 4 types): 10% of total grade
Flashcard Mastery (Box 7): 15% of total grade
Pronunciation/Reading (10%)
Daily Read-Aloud practice: 10% of total grade (completion + self-check)
Note: There is no conversation component for Latin. This category focuses on accurate pronunciation of Latin text using either Classical or Ecclesiastical pronunciation.
Unit Tests (20%)
Each of the 10 unit tests: 2% of total grade
Cumulative Exams (20%)
Midterm Exam (Capita I–XX): 8% of total grade
Final Exam (Capita I–XL): 12% of total grade
5. Pronunciation & Reading Component
Latin pronunciation is assessed through reading aloud rather than conversation. Students should choose either Classical or Ecclesiastical pronunciation and maintain consistency.

sections.heading: 5.1 Daily Read-Aloud
content: For each chapter, the student:
Records themselves reading the chapter vocabulary and practice sentences
Compares their recording to reference audio (see sources below)
Self-assesses focusing on: vowel quantity, consonant sounds, stress patterns
Parent spot-checks periodically

sections.heading: 5.2 Pronunciation Systems
content: Classical Pronunciation (Restored)
C always hard (like K): Cicero = "Kikero"
G always hard (like in "go"): genus = "genus" (not "jenus")
V pronounced as W: vīnum = "weenum"
AE and OE as diphthongs: puellae = "poo-EL-lai"
Ecclesiastical Pronunciation (Church Latin)
C soft before E, I, AE, OE (like CH): Cicero = "Chichero"
G soft before E, I (like J): genus = "jenus"
V pronounced as V: vīnum = "veenum"
AE and OE as "ay": puellae = "poo-EL-lay"
6. Reward Point Values
Points are earned for each completed component. These points feed directly into the reward system.

sections.heading: 6.2 Flashcard Mastery Points
content: Each flashcard that reaches Leitner Box 7 earns a one-time graduation bonus. Latin uses four specialized card types.
Note: Vocabulary cards MUST include the full dictionary entry (e.g., puella, -ae, f. = girl) to earn full points. Cards with incomplete entries earn only 5 points.

sections.heading: 6.4 Locī Antīquī Bonus Points
content: Reading authentic Latin texts from the Locī Antīquī and Locī Immūtātī sections earns bonus points. These are optional but highly encouraged.
7. Bonuses & Multipliers

sections.heading: 7.1 Streak Bonuses
content: Completing chapter work on consecutive days earns streak multipliers applied to daily practice points.

sections.heading: 7.3 Milestone Bonuses
content: 8. Thematic Mastery Badges
Each chapter is tagged by grammatical theme. Completing all chapters in a theme AND graduating all associated flashcards to Box 7 earns a Mastery Badge.

sections.heading: 8.1 Badge Categories
tables: All 1st decl. content + cards to Box 7
All 2nd decl. content + cards to Box 7
All 3rd decl. content + cards to Box 7
All 4th decl. content + cards to Box 7
All 5th decl. content + cards to Box 7
All active tenses + cards to Box 7
All passive tenses + cards to Box 7
All subjunctive content (Cap. XXVIII–XXXVI) + cards to Box 7
All participle/gerund content + cards to Box 7
All syntax pattern cards to Box 7

sections.heading: 8.2 Badge Requirements
content: To earn a Mastery Badge (except Translation Master), a student must:
Complete all chapters containing that theme
Create all flashcards for those chapters
Graduate ALL associated flashcards to Leitner Box 7
Score 80%+ average on unit tests covering those chapters
9. Chapter-to-Theme Mapping
Below is the mapping of all 40 chapters to their thematic tags. Chapters may have multiple tags.

sections.heading: 9.1 Declensions
content: 1st Declension: Chapters II, XVI (adjectives)
2nd Declension: Chapters III (masc.), IV (neuters), XVI (adjectives)
3rd Declension: Chapters VII, XIV (i-stems), XVI (adjectives)
4th Declension: Chapter XX
5th Declension: Chapter XXII

sections.heading: 9.2 Conjugations & Tenses
content: 1st/2nd Conjugation: Chapters I, V, XVIII, XXI
3rd Conjugation: Chapters VIII, X, XXI
4th Conjugation: Chapters X, XXI
Perfect Active: Chapter XII
Passive Voice: Chapters XVIII, XIX, XXI
Irregular Verbs: Sum (IV, VI), Possum (VI), Ferō (XXXI), Volō/Mālō/Nōlō (XXXII), Fīō (XXXVI), Eō (XXXVII)

sections.heading: 9.3 Subjunctive
content: Present Subjunctive: Chapter XXVIII
Imperfect Subjunctive: Chapter XXIX
Perfect/Pluperfect Subjunctive: Chapter XXX
Subjunctive Uses: Chapters XXVIII–XXX (Purpose, Result, Indirect Questions), XXXI (Cum), XXXIII (Conditions), XXXVI (Jussive Noun), XL (Fear)

sections.heading: 9.4 Participles & Verbal Nouns
content: Participles: Chapter XXIII
Ablative Absolute: Chapter XXIV
Infinitives: Chapter XXV
Gerund/Gerundive: Chapter XXXIX
Supines: Chapter XXXVIII

sections.heading: 9.5 Syntax Patterns
content: Ablative Uses: Chapters XIV (Means, Accompaniment, Manner), XVIII (Agent), XX (Place, Separation), XXII (Summary), XXVI (Comparison)
Dative Uses: Chapters XXIV (Agent with Passive Periphrastic), XXXV (with Adjectives/Verbs/Compounds), XXXVIII (Reference)
Genitive Uses: Chapters XV (Whole), XL (Description)
Indirect Statement: Chapter XXV
10. Maximum Point Totals
The following summarizes the maximum possible points a student can earn in Wheelock's Latin.

sections.heading: 10.3 Flashcard Mastery (estimated)
content: Estimated cards: ~25 vocab/chapter, ~2 declension paradigms, ~3 conjugation paradigms, ~2 syntax patterns

sections.heading: 10.5 Grand Total
content: 11. Grade Scale
12. Implementation Notes

sections.heading: 12.1 Textbook + Workbook Integration
content: Both textbook and workbook exercises must be completed for each chapter
Textbook and Workbook are weighted equally (12.5% each of total grade)
Self-Tutorial Exercises (p. 412) can be used for additional practice

sections.heading: 12.2 Latin-Specific Flashcard Rules
content: Vocabulary cards MUST include full dictionary entry: puella, -ae, f. (not just "puella")
Verb entries must include all principal parts: amō, amāre, amāvī, amātum
Declension cards should show full paradigm (all cases, singular and plural)
Conjugation cards should show full paradigm for the specific tense/voice
Macrons (long marks) should be included: ā, ē, ī, ō, ū

sections.heading: 12.3 Pronunciation Practice
content: Choose either Classical or Ecclesiastical pronunciation and maintain consistency
Focus on vowel quantity (long vs. short) and proper stress placement
Record readings for self-assessment and parent review

sections.heading: 12.4 Reference Audio Sources
content: Wheelock's Latin audio companion (if available)
Latinitium.com (Classical pronunciation resources)
YouTube: ScorpioMartianus, Latina Vivit (spoken Latin content)
Vatican website (for Ecclesiastical pronunciation)

sections.heading: 12.5 Locī Antīquī Integration
content: Locī Antīquī passages are OPTIONAL but earn significant bonus points
Begin with guided readings (vocabulary help provided)
Progress to independent readings as skills develop
Locī Immūtātī (unadapted) readings should be attempted after completing the textbook or alongside later chapters
— Fīnis —
